newsitem.title: USA: Top Hollywood hairdresser Guilaroff dies.
newsitem.headline: Top Hollywood hairdresser Guilaroff dies.

text.p: Sydney Guilaroff, considered by many to be the greatest hairdresser in Hollywood history, who created "the look" for the top MGM female stars, died on Wednesday. He was 89.

Guilaroff, credited with giving Claudette Colbert her distinctive bangs and turning a naturally blonde Lucille Ball into a redhead, died at the Beverly Hills Rehabilitation Centre after a long illness, a spokeswoman said.
Discovered in New York in the 1930's by Joan Crawford, Guilaroff was the first hairdresser to be given a screen credit for his work.
The spokeswoman said actor Roddy McDowell had recently lobbied the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to have a special award given to Guilaroff.
The English-born stylist, who grew up in Winnipeg, Manitoba, also counted many of Hollywood's greatest beauties as his friends and wrote about them in his recently published memoirs.

He began his MGM career doing Greta Garbo's hair for "Camille." He followed with other classic coiffes such as Norma Shearer as "Marie Antoinette," Marlene Dietrich in "Kismet," Vivien Leigh in "Gone With the Wind" and Debbie Reynolds in "Singin' in the Rain."
He was a stylist of choice for Ava Gardner, Marilyn Monroe, Natalie Wood, Shirley MacLaine and Elizabeth Taylor.
Guilaroff is survived by two sons.
